{{Year box}} [[Image:Mary Browne.jpg|thumb|250px|right|American tennis champion [[Mary Browne]]]] '''1912 in sports''' describes the year's events in world sport.
==[[American football]]== '''College championship''' * [[NCAA Division I FBS National Football Championship|College football national championship]] – [[Harvard Crimson]]
==[[Association football]]== '''Brazil''' * [[Santos FC]], officially founded on April 14.{{citation needed|date=December 2016}} '''England''' * [[The Football League]] – [[Blackburn Rovers]] 49 points, [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] 46, [[Newcastle United]] 44, [[Bolton Wanderers]] 43, [[Sheffield Wednesday|The Wednesday]] 41, [[Aston Villa]] 41 * 20 April: [[1912 FA Cup Final|FA Cup final]] – [[Barnsley FC|Barnsley]] 1–0 [[West Bromwich Albion]] at [[Crystal Palace National Sports Centre|Crystal Palace]], London (replay following 0–0 draw at Crystal Palace) '''Germany''' * [[List of German football champions|National Championship]] – [[Holstein Kiel]] 1–0 [[Karlsruher FV]] at Hamburg-Hoheluft '''Iceland''' * Iceland's premier division, now known as [[Landsbankadeild]], is established with [[KR Reykjavík|KR]] winning the inaugural title. '''Russia''' * 19 January — formation of the All-Russian Football Union (VRS) which is now the [[Russian Football Union]]; from 1935 to 1992 it is subsumed by the [[Football Federation of USSR]]. '''Scotland''' * [[Scottish Football League]] – [[Rangers F.C.|Rangers]] * [[1912 Scottish Cup Final|Scottish Cup]] – [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]] 2–0 [[Clyde F.C.|Clyde]] at [[Ibrox Stadium|Ibrox Park]]
==[[Track and field athletics|Athletics]]== '''Men's 100 metres''' * The first world record in the [[100 metres]] for men is recognised by the International Amateur Athletics Federation, now known as the [[International Association of Athletics Federations]] (IAAF), after [[Donald Lippincott]] (USA) runs a time of 10.6 at [[Stockholm]]. '''Men's 1500 metres''' * The first world record in the [[1500 metres]] for men is recognised by the IAAF after [[Abel Kiviat]] (USA) runs a time of 3:55.8 at [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]].
==[[Australian rules football]]== '''AFL Premiership''' * [[Essendon Football Club|Essendon]] wins the 16th [[Australian Football League|VFL]] Premiership: Essendon 5.17 (47) d [[Sydney Swans|South Melbourne]] 4.9 (33) at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] (MCG)
==[[Bandy]]== '''Sweden''' * [[Allsvenskan and Elitserien (bandy)|Championship final]] – [[IFK Uppsala Bandy|IFK Uppsala]] 1–1 [[Djurgårdens IF Bandy|Djurgårdens IF]] (declared a tie; no replay played)
==[[Baseball]]== '''World Series''' * 8–16 October — [[Boston Red Sox]] (AL) defeats [[New York Giants (NL)|New York Giants]] (NL) to win the [[1912 World Series]] by 4 games to 3 with one tie '''Events''' * 20 April — [[Boston Red Sox]] open the new [[Fenway Park]] with a 7–6 11-inning win over [[New York Yankees]] before 27,000. Minutes later, the [[Detroit Tigers]] open the remodelled Navin Park (later named [[Tiger Stadium (Detroit)|Tiger Stadium]]) with a 6–5 11-inning win over [[Cleveland Indians]] before 24,384. * [[Winnipeg Maroons]] win the [[Northern League (baseball, 1902–71)|Northern League]] championship
==[[Boxing]]== '''Events''' * 22 February — [[Johnny Kilbane]] wins the [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship when he defeats [[Abe Attell]] over 20 rounds at Vernon, California. Attell has held the title since 1903; Kilbane will hold it until 1923. * 28 November — [[Ad Wolgast]] loses his [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship to [[Willie Ritchie]] following a 16th round foul at Colma, California. Ritchie holds the title until 1914. '''Lineal world champions'''<ref>[http://www.cyberboxingzone.com/boxing/pastchp.htm Cyber Boxing Zone]</ref> * [[World Heavyweight Champion]]ship – [[Jack Johnson (boxer)|Jack Johnson]] * [[World Light Heavyweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Middleweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Welterweight Champion]]ship – vacant * [[World Lightweight Champion]]ship – [[Ad Wolgast]] → [[Willie Ritchie]] * [[World Featherweight Champion]]ship – [[Abe Attell]] → [[Johnny Kilbane]] * [[World Bantamweight Champion]]ship – [[Johnny Coulon]]
==[[Canadian football]]== '''Grey Cup''' * 30 November — [[4th Grey Cup]] – [[Hamilton Alerts]] 11–4 [[Toronto Argonauts]]
==[[Cricket]]== '''Events''' * A triangular [[Test cricket|Test]] tournament is played in England between [[England national cricket team|England]], [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] and [[South Africa national cricket team|South Africa]]. England wins with Australia second. '''England''' * [[County Championship]] – [[Yorkshire CCC|Yorkshire]] * [[Minor Counties Championship]] – ''in abeyance'' * Most runs – [[David Denton (cricketer)|David Denton]] 2127 @ 42.54 (HS 221) * Most wickets – [[Colin Blythe]] 178 @ 12.26 (BB 8–36) * [[Wisden Cricketers of the Year]] – ''no award'' '''Australia''' * [[Sheffield Shield]] – [[New South Wales cricket team|New South Wales]] * Most runs – [[Wilfred Rhodes]] 1098 @ 54.90 (HS 179) * Most wickets – [[Frank Foster (cricketer)|Frank Foster]] 62 @ 20.19 (BB 7–36) '''India''' * [[Bombay Quadrangular|Bombay Triangular]] – [[Parsees cricket team|Parsees]] '''New Zealand''' * [[Plunket Shield]] – [[Auckland cricket team|Auckland]] '''South Africa''' * [[SuperSport Series|Currie Cup]] – ''not contested'' '''West Indies''' * [[Inter-Colonial Tournament]] – [[Barbados cricket team|Barbados]]
==[[Cycling]]== '''Tour de France''' * [[Odile Defraye]] (Belgium) wins the 10th [[1912 Tour de France|Tour de France]]
==[[Figure skating]]== '''World Figure Skating Championships''' * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Men's Champion]] – Fritz Kachler (Austria) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Women's Champion]] – Opika von Méray Horváth (Hungary) * [[World Figure Skating Championships|World Pairs Champions]] – Phyllis Johnson / James H. Johnson (Great Britain)
==[[Golf]]== '''Major tournaments''' * [[1911 Open Championship|British Open]] – [[Ted Ray (golfer)|Ted Ray]] * [[1911 U.S. Open (golf)|US Open]] – [[John McDermott (golfer)|John McDermott]] '''Other tournaments''' * [[The Amateur Championship|British Amateur]] – [[John Ball (golfer)|John Ball]] * [[United States Amateur Championship (men's golf)|US Amateur]] – [[Jerome Travers]]
==[[Horse racing]]== '''England''' * [[1912 Grand National|Grand National]] – Jerry M * [[1,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Tagalie]] * [[2,000 Guineas Stakes]] – [[Sweeper (horse)|Sweeper II]] * [[Epsom Derby|The Derby]] – Tagalie * [[Epsom Oaks|The Oaks]] – [[Mirska]] * [[St. Leger Stakes]] – [[Tracery (horse)|Tracery]] ''''Australia''' * [[Melbourne Cup]] – Piastre '''Canada''' * [[Queen's Plate]] – Heresy '''Ireland''' * [[Irish Grand National]] – Small Polly * [[Irish Derby Stakes]] – Civility '''USA''' * [[1912 Kentucky Derby|Kentucky Derby]] – [[Worth (horse)|Worth]] * [[Preakness Stakes]] – [[Colonel Holloway]] * [[Belmont Stakes]] – ''not contested due to anti-betting legislation in New York State''
==[[Ice hockey]]== '''Stanley Cup''' * [[Quebec Bulldogs]] wins the [[National Hockey Association]] (NHA) championship and the [[Stanley Cup]]. Quebec then defeats [[Moncton]] in a Cup challenge. '''Events''' * March — [[Winnipeg Victorias]] repeats as [[1912 Allan Cup|Allan Cup]] winners * March — [[New Westminster Royals]] wins the inaugural [[Pacific Coast Hockey Association]] (PCHA) championship * December — Toronto NHA teams, the Blueshirts and Tecumsehs, join the NHA
==[[Motorsport]]== {{main|1912 in motorsport}}
==[[Olympic Games]]== '''1912 Summer Olympics''' * The [[1912 Summer Olympics]] takes place in [[Stockholm]] * First usage of electronic timing and public address systems * Sweden wins the most medals (65) and United States the most gold medals (25)
==[[Rowing (sport)|Rowing]]== '''The Boat Race''' * 1 April — [[Oxford University Boat Club|Oxford]] wins the 69th [[The Boat Race 1912|Oxford and Cambridge Boat Race]]
==[[Rugby league]]== '''England''' * [[Rugby Football League Championship|Championship]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] * [[Challenge Cup|Challenge Cup final]] – [[Dewsbury Rams|Dewsbury]] 8–5 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] at [[Headingley Rugby Stadium]], [[Leeds]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Lancashire League Championship]] – [[Wigan Warriors|Wigan]] * [[Rugby league county leagues|Yorkshire League Championship]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] * [[RFL Lancashire Cup|Lancashire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Rochdale Hornets]] 12–5 [[Oldham R.L.F.C.|Oldham]] * [[RFL Yorkshire Cup|Yorkshire]] [[Rugby league county cups|County Cup]] – [[Huddersfield Giants|Huddersfield]] 22–10 [[Hull Kingston Rovers]] '''International''' * [[The Ashes (rugby league)|The Ashes]] are won by [[Australian rugby league team|Australia]] as they defeat Great Britain 33–8 in the 3rd Test of the [[1911–12 Kangaroo tour of Great Britain]] at [[Villa Park]] before a crowd of 4,000. '''Australia''' * [[New South Wales Rugby League premiership|NSW Premiership]] – [[Sydney Roosters|Eastern Suburbs]] (outright winner)
==[[Rugby union]]== '''Five Nations Championship''' * 30th [[1912 Five Nations Championship|Five Nations Championship]] series is shared by [[England national rugby union team|England]] and [[Ireland national rugby union team|Ireland]]
==[[Speed skating]]== '''Speed Skating World Championships''' * [[1912 World Allround Speed Skating Championships|Men's All-round Champion]] – [[Oscar Mathisen]] (Norway)
==[[Tennis]]== '''Australia''' * [[List of Australian Open Men's Singles champions|Australian Men's Singles Championship]] – [[James Cecil Parke]] (GC) defeats [[Alfred Beamish]] (GB) 3–6 6–3 1–6 6–1 7–5 '''England''' * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Anthony Wilding]] (New Zealand) defeats [[Arthur Gore (tennis)|Arthur Gore]] (GB) 6–4 6–4 4–6 6–4 * [[The Championships, Wimbledon|Wimbledon Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Ethel Thomson Larcombe]] defeats [[Charlotte Cooper Sterry]] 6–3 6–1 '''France''' * [[List of French Open Men's Singles champions and finalists|French Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Max Decugis]] defeats [[André Gobert]]: details unknown * [[List of French Open Women's Singles champions|French Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Jeanne Matthey]] defeats Danet: details unknown '''USA''' * [[US Open (tennis)|American Men's Singles Championship]] – [[Maurice McLoughlin]] defeats [[Wallace F. Johnson|Wallace Johnson]] 3–6 2–6 6–2 6–4 6–2 * [[US Open (tennis)|American Women's Singles Championship]] – [[Mary Browne]] defeats [[Eleonora Sears]] 6–4 6–2 '''Davis Cup''' * [[1912 International Lawn Tennis Challenge]] – {{davis|GBR|name=British Isles}} 3–2 {{davis|Australasia}} at [[Albert Park and Lake|Albert Ground]] (grass) [[Melbourne]], Australia
==References== {{Reflist}}

{{TennisEventInfo|2004|J&S Cup| | date=April 26 – May 2 | edition=9th | champs={{flagicon|USA}} [[Venus Williams]] | champd={{flagicon|ITA}} [[Silvia Farina Elia]] / {{flagicon|ITA}} [[Francesca Schiavone]] }} The '''2004 [[J&S Cup]]''' was a Tier II [[tennis]] event on the 2004 WTA Tour that run from April 26 - May 2, 2004. It was held in [[Warsaw]], Poland, and was the 9th year that the event was staged. The [[2003 J&S Cup]] finalist [[Venus Williams]] won her first Warsaw title and second overall of the year. ==Entrants== ===Seeds=== {| class="wikitable" border="1" |- ! Player ! Nationality ! Ranking* ! Seeding |- | [[Amélie Mauresmo]] | {{flagicon|FRA|}} France | 3 | 1 |- | [[Venus Williams]] | {{flagicon|USA|}} United States | 4 | 2 |- | [[Vera Zvonareva]] | {{flagicon|RUS|}} Russia | 11 | 3 |- | [[Svetlana Kuznetsova]] | {{flagicon|RUS|}} Russia | 14 | 4 |- | [[Paola Suárez]] | {{flagicon|ARG|}} [[Argentina]] | 15 | 5 |- | [[Silvia Farina Elia]] | {{flagicon|ITA|}} Italy | 16 | 6 |- | [[Patty Schnyder]] | {{flagicon|SUI|}} Switzerland | 17 | 7 |- | [[Anna Smashnova-Pistolesi]] | {{flagicon|ISR|}} [[Israel]] | 20 | 8 |- | [[Francesca Schiavone]] | {{flagicon|ITA|}} Italy | 22 | 9 |} * Seedings are based on the rankings of April 19, 2004. * Paola Suárez (no. 5 seed) withdrew from the tournament due to low back pain; Francesca Schiavone became the no. 9 seed. ===Other entrants=== The following players received [[Wild card (sports)|wildcard]]s into the main draw: * {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Vera Douchevina]] * {{flagicon|POL}} [[Marta Domachowska]] The following players received entry from the qualifying draw: * {{flagicon|SVK}} [[Henrieta Nagyová]] * {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Květa Peschke]] * {{flagicon|USA}} [[Kristen Schlukebir]] * {{flagicon|UKR}} [[Elena Tatarkova]] The following players received entry as Lucky Losers: * {{flagicon|CZE}} [[Lenka Němečková]] ==Champions== ===Singles=== {{main|2004 J&S Cup - Singles}} '''{{flagicon|USA}} [[Venus Williams]]''' def. {{flagicon|RUS}} [[Svetlana Kuznetsova]], 6-1, 6-4 ---- ===Doubles=== {{main|2004 J&S Cup - Doubles}} {{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[Silvia Farina Elia]]''' / {{flagicon|ITA}} '''[[Francesca Schiavone]]''' def. {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Gisela Dulko]] / {{flagicon|ARG}} [[Patricia Tarabini]], 3-6, 6-2, 6-1 ==External links== *[http://www.sonyericssonwtatour.com/tournaments/profiles/warsaw.asp WTA Profile] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121005120637/http://www.wtatennis.com/SEWTATour-Archive/Archive/Draws/2004/680.pdf Singles, Doubles and Qualifying Singles Draws]

{{Other uses|AS Police (disambiguation){{!}}AS Police}} {{Football club infobox | clubname = AS Police | image = | fullname = Association Sportive Police | nickname = | founded = | ground = Municipal de ASC Police | capacity = 5,000 }} '''Association Sportive Police''', commonly referred to as '''AS Police''', is a [[Senegal]]ese [[association football]] club based in [[Dakar]].
The club was also formerly known as: *''Association Sportive et Culturelle de Police'' (ASC Police) *''Association Sportive et Culturelle Forces de Police'' (ASF Police)
==Achievements== *[[Senegal Premier League]]: '''1''' (1979) *[[Senegal FA Cup]]: '''3''' (1976, 1978, 1981) *Coupe de l'Assemblée Nationale: '''2''' (1979, 1981)
==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[African Cup of Champions Clubs]]: 1 appearance''' :[[1980 African Cup of Champions Clubs|1980]]: Quarter-finals

The club currently plays in [[Gabon Championnat National D2]] In 1968 and 1969 the team has won the [[Gabon Championnat National D1]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/tablesg/gabchamp.html|title=Gabon - List of Champions|website=www.rsssf.com|access-date=2018-04-16}} ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 7000 capacity [[Stade Augustin Monédan de Sibang]]. ==Honours== *'''[[Gabon Championnat National D1]]''' :Champion (2): 1968, 1969 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1970 African Cup of Champions Clubs|1970]] – First Round ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.calciopedia.org/statistiche/africa/476-statistiche-gabon Gabon Campionato] – ''calciopedia.org'' [[Category:Football clubs in Gabon]] {{Gabon-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox person | name = Ali Almslmani
علي المسلماني | image = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = Ali Hassan Al-Mosllamani | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1984|3|4}} | birth_place = [[Doha]], Qatar | death_date = | death_place = | nationality = {{flag|Qatar}} | other_names = | residence = [[Qatar]] | occupation = Sport anchor, TV Host & writer | years_active =2003–present | alma_mater = | known_for = [[Al Jazeera]] | notable_works = }} '''Ali Hassan Al-Mosllamani''' well known '''Ali Almslmani''' (Arabic: '''علي المسلماني''') (born 4 March 1984) is a [[Qatar]]i , Sport anchor{{cite web|url=https://www.goal.com/ar/news/3360/%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%A9/2011/10/31/2735572/%D9%85%D9%82%D8%A7%D8%A8%D9%84%D8%A9-%D8%AE%D8%A7%D8%B5%D8%A9-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D8%A3%D9%81%D8%B6%D9%84-%D9%85%D8%B4%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AF%D8%A9-%D9%85%D9%8A%D8%B3%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AF%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7|title=مقابلة خاصة - علي المسلماني: أفضّل مشاهدة ميسي على مارادونا والدوريان المصري والسعودي الأقوى - Goal.com|website=www.goal.com}}, [[television]] presenter{{cite web|url=https://www.al-sharq.com/news/details/458888|title=المسلماني: شبابنا اختصروا على أنفسهم أميالاً طويلة في درب الإحترافية|publisher=}}, [[television]] hosthttp://www.al-watan.com/news-details/id/9276/d/20160618%20class=, [[interview]]er, and writer on [[Al Jazeera]] since 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.alarab.qa/story/219597/%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%88%D8%AC%D9%87-%D9%82%D8%B7%D8%B1%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%89-%D8%B4%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A9|title=العرب القطرية: المسلماني.. وجه قطري على شاشة الجزيرة|website=العرب القطرية}}http://www.dc4mf.org/news/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A-%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%B2-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%AD%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%87%D8%AA%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF/{{cite web|url=http://www.raya.com/mob/miscellaneous/2017/1/5/%D8%B9%D9%85%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A8%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D8%AE%D8%AA%D8%B5%D8%B1-%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%B9%D9%82%D9%88%D8%AF%D8%A7-%D9%85%D9%86-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AA%D8%B7%D9%88%D8%B1-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%87%D9%86%D9%8A|title=جريدة الراية - عملي بالجزيرة اختصر عليّ عقوداً من التطور المهني|website=www.raya.com}} ==Bio== '''Ali Almslmani''' born in [[Doha]]. He began his media career in [[2003]], commenting on [[Qatar TV]]. He was then the youngest [[Arab]] commentator, where he was only 19 years old at the time. He covered the [[Asian Cup]] in China in 2004 as the youngest media player in the tournament as well as covering the [[Gulf Cup]] in [[Doha]], crowned by the [[Qatar]]i team. He then moved to [[Al Kass Sports Channels]], one of its members since its inception, and commented on many sporting events locally and internationally, in conjunction with his chairmanship of editing the program of our children in cooperation with Aspire Academy of Sports Excellence "[[Aspire Dome]]". Al-Mosllamani also holds an accredited diploma from [[Al Jazeera]] Center for Training and Media Development in preparing, presenting and directing radio programs where he worked for six years in "Radio Sawt Al-Khaleej" as a presenter of [[sport]]s [[Radio program|program]]s and [[news]]. Al-Mosllamani moved to [[Al Jazeera]]{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/programs/broadcasters/2013/12/13/%D8%B9%D9%84%D9%8A-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D8%B3%D9%84%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%8A|title=علي المسلماني|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://sport.aljazeera.net/championsleague/2018/2/20/%D8%AA%D9%88%D9%82%D8%B9%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%86%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%A6%D8%AC-%D8%AB%D9%85%D9%86-%D9%86%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%A6%D9%8A-%D8%A3%D8%A8%D8%B7%D8%A7%D9%84-%D8%A3%D9%88%D8%B1%D9%88%D8%A8%D8%A7-%D8%A8%D9%80-%D8%B1%D9%8A%D8%A7%D8%B6%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A9|title=توقعات نتائج ثمن نهائي أبطال أوروبا بـ"رياضة الجزيرة"|publisher=}} in 2008 and was the only [[Qatar]]i in the newsroom where he worked as a [[journalist]] and then as an assistant producer before becoming a certified sports news producer two years ago. Al-Mosllamani holds a diploma in [[Television]], and is the first in two courses in [[television]] presentation, starting from [[Al Jazeera]] Training and Development Center with "Ms. [[Laila Al Shaikhli]]" and in the television news presentation with Ms. [[Khadija Benguenna]] with a degree of excellence before being approved by Al Jazeera Management. December 2012. Ali has a course in media management and planning, management of newsrooms, human resource management from Cambridge College and a new career in his nearly 10 years of career. [[Al Jazeera]] has been officially invited to the list of Al Jazeera broadcasters in advance of the news and sports briefs broadcast by the first Arabic channel, thus becoming the latest Qatari faces after Khaled Saleh and Mohammed Al Marri and the first after Ahmed Bin Jassim Bin Mohammed Al Thani was appointed Director General of the network.{{cite web|url=http://www.al-watan.com/news-details/id/137614|title=تألق المسلماني عريف الحفل|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.alarab.qa/story/1315911/%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AC%D8%B2%D9%8A%D8%B1%D8%A9-%D9%84%D9%84%D8%A5%D8%B9%D9%84%D8%A7%D9%85-%D9%8A%D8%B7%D9%84%D9%82-%D8%AF%D9%88%D8%B1%D8%A7%D8%AA-%D9%84%D9%84%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%A1-%D9%85%D8%B7%D9%84%D8%B9-%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%84%D9%8A%D9%88|title=العرب القطرية: «الجزيرة للإعلام» يطلق دورات للنشء مطلع يوليو|website=العرب القطرية}}{{cite web|url=https://www.arrajol.com/content/103591/%D9%87%D8%A7%D8%B4%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%AC/%D9%81%D9%8A-%D9%85%D9%88%D9%82%D8%B9%D8%A9-%D9%85%D8%A7%D9%86%D8%B4%D8%B3%D8%AA%D8%B1-%D9%8A%D9%88%D9%86%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%AA%D8%AF-%D9%88%D8%AA%D9%88%D8%AA%D9%86%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%85-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%A8%D8%AF%D9%8A%D9%84-%C2%AB%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D9%88%D8%A8%D8%B1%C2%BB-%D9%8A%D8%AD%D8%B3%D9%85-%D9%82%D9%85%D8%A9-%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%B3%D8%A8%D8%AA-%D8%A7%D9%84%D9%85%D9%85%D8%AA%D8%A7%D8%B2|title=في page.title: Best U.S. Male Olympian ESPY Award

revision.text:
The '''Best U.S. Male Olympian [[ESPY Award]]''' has been presented annually since [[2009 in sports|2009]] to the [[Sportsperson|sportsman]] or [[team sports|team]] affiliated with the [[United States Olympic Committee]] and contesting [[List of sports|sport]] [[international]]ly adjudged to be the best. The award serves in practice to replace the [[Best Male Olympic Performance ESPY Award]], which was presented in [[2005 in sports|2005]], and the [[Best U.S. Olympian ESPY Award]] presented in 2006. [[Voting|Balloting]] for the award is undertaken by [[fan (aficionado)|fan]]s over the [[Internet]] from amongst between three and five choices selected by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee, and the award is conferred in June to reflect performance and achievement over the twelve months previous. ==List of winners== {| class="wikitable" |- style="white-space: nowrap;" !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Year !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Athlete !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Sport and discipline or event contested !style="background: #e3e3e3;"|Other nominees |- |[[2009 ESPY Awards|2009]] |[[Michael Phelps]] |[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] |[[Bryan Clay]] (Track & Field) ---- [[LaShawn Merritt]] (Track & Field) ---- [[Angelo Taylor]] (Track & Field) |- |[[2010 ESPY Awards|2010]] |[[Shaun White]]http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/news/story?id=5381428 |[[Snowboarding]] ([[halfpipe]]) ||[[Apolo Anton Ohno]] (Speedskating)
[[Shani Davis]] (Speedskating)
[[Evan Lysacek]] (Figure Skating)
[[Bode Miller]] (Skiing) |- |[[2011 ESPY Awards|2011]] |No Award Presented |- |[[2012 ESPY Awards|2012]] |No Award Presented |- |[[2013 ESPY Awards|2013]] |[[Michael Phelps]] |[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] |[[Ashton Eaton]] (Decathlon) ---- [[Ryan Lochte]] (Swimming) |- |[[2014 ESPY Awards|2014]] |[[Sage Kotsenburg]] |[[Snowboarding]] ([[slopestyle]]) |[[Joss Christensen]] (Slopestyle skiing)
[[Ted Ligety]] (Alpine skiing)
[[Charlie White (figure skater)|Charlie White]] (Ice Dancing)
[[David Wise (freestyle skier)|David Wise]] (Halfpipe Skiing) |- |[[2015 ESPY Awards|2015]] |No Award Presented |- |[[2016 ESPY Awards|2016]] |No Award Presented |- |[[2017 ESPY Awards|2017]] |[[Michael Phelps]] |[[Swimming (sport)|Swimming]] |[[Ashton Eaton]] (Decathlon) ---- [[Ryan Murphy (swimmer)|Ryan Murphy]] (Swimming) ---- [[Kyle Snyder (wrestler)|Kyle Snyder]] (Wrestler) |- |} ==See also== *[[USOC Sportsman of the Year Award]] *[[USOC Team of the Year|USOC Team of the Year Award]] *[[United States at the Olympics]] *[[United States Olympic Hall of Fame]] *[[Best U.S. Female Olympian ESPY Award]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{ESPYs}} [[Category:ESPY Awards]] [[Category:American sports trophies and awards]] [[Category:United States at the Olympics]]

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=November 2009}} [[Image:Chemungspeedromelogo.png|thumb|right|Chemung Speedrome in Chemung, New York.]] The '''Chemung Speedrome''' is a 3/8 mile Asphalt race track in [[Chemung, New York|Chemung]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[United States|USA]]. Built in 1951 by the Bodine family, the track was first dirt-surfaced, then paved. It was closed in 1978. After buying the track in 1985, one of the current owners Bob Stapleton started to rebuild the track in 1997, and in 2000 the track held its inaugural event. ==Track Operators== '''Owner:''' John White-Bob Stapleton
'''Race Director:''' .Ray Hodge
'''Office Managers:''' Kathy Grodski
'''Announcers:''' Carol Houssock '''Tech Inspector:''' Chester Bennett '''Scorers:''' Dale Campbell '''Head Flagger:''' Allen Mathews '''Handicapper:''' '''Scoreboard:''' '''Concession Manager:''' '''Track Photographer:''' '''Track Videographer: Race Report Productions www.TheRaceReport.TV '''Pace Car Driver:''' Billy Griffin ==Events held at the Speedrome== Whelen All American Series, INEX Legends, Bandoleros. Past Events: The NASCAR Weekly Racing Series NASCAR Whelen Modified Tour ISMA Super Modifieds Race Of Champions Modified Tour USAR Hooters Pro Cup Series SST Modified Tour Cup Lite Racing Series USAC Ford Focus Midget Series ==Facilities== The Chemung Speedrome features all new TV quality [[Musco Lighting]], a 3000 seat main grandstand, a 28 stall paved pit lane and much more. The facility is situated on {{convert|38|acre|m2}}. ==Friday Night Sister Speedway== [[Spencer Speedway]] - [[Williamson, New York|Williamson]], [[New York (state)|New York]] ==External links== * [http://www.chemungspeedrome.net Official Website] {{Coord|42.024814|-76.624146|display=title}} [[Category:Motorsport venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:NASCAR tracks]] [[Category:Sports venues in Chemung County, New York]] [[Category:1951 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1951]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Fenner's | nickname = | image = Fenners1.jpg | country = England | location = [[Cambridge]], [[England]] | establishment = 1848 | owner = Cambridge University Cricket & Athletics Company Ltd | end1 = Pavilion End | end2 = Gresham Road End | year1 = 1848 – present | club1 = [[Cambridge University Cricket Club]] | date = 29 October | year = 2018 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/374.html CricketArchive }}[[Image:Fenners2.jpg|thumb|200px|right|The indoor cricket school]] '''Fenner's''' is [[Cambridge University Cricket Club]]'s ground.
==History== Fenner's has hosted [[first-class cricket]] since 1848, and many of the world's great players have graced the wicket. The ground was established on land leased for the purpose by [[Francis Fenner]], after whom the ground is named.<ref name="cricgnd">{{cite web|url=http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/56861.html|title=Fenner's|publisher=CricInfo|accessdate=22 September 2008}}</ref>
Playing for [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]] has launched many careers: such names as [[Peter May (cricketer)|Peter May]], [[David Sheppard]], [[Ted Dexter]], [[Tony Lewis]] and [[Mike Brearley]] to [[Jahangir Khan (cricketer)|Jahangir Khan]], [[Derek Pringle]], [[John Crawley]], [[Steve James (cricketer)|Steve James]], [[Mike Atherton]], [[Ed Smith (cricketer)|Ed Smith]] and the most recent [[Cambridge University Cricket Club]] player to be selected for the [[English cricket team|England team]], [[Zafar Ansari]].
Fenner's is also home to the [[Cambridge MCC University]] side, a partnership between the [[University of Cambridge]], [[Anglia Ruskin University]] and the [[Marylebone Cricket Club]] established ahead of the 2010 season.
==Facilities== As well as the cricket ground, there is a 3-lane indoor cricket school.
The groundsman pioneered the art of mowing grass in strips to create patterns, a technique now common in sports stadiums around the world.<ref name="Allen p113">{{cite book |last= Allen |first= Peter |title= The Invincibles: The Legend of Bradman's 1948 Australians |year=1999 |publisher= Allen and Kemsley |location=Mosman, NSW, Australia |isbn= 1-875171-06-1}} p. 103</ref>
== See also == * [[The Parks]], where first-class cricket is played in [[Oxford]] * [[University Ground, Barnwell]], a former Cambridge University cricket ground
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150415054302/http://www.sport.cam.ac.uk/facilities/fenners-cricket-ground/index.html Fenner's home page] * [https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/374.html Matches played at Fenner's] from CricketArchive * [http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/56861.html Ground profile] from [[Cricinfo]] * [http://www.cucc.net Cambridge University Cricket Club]
{{Cambridge University Cricket Club}} {{coord|52|12|00.43|N|0|07|54.62|E|region:GB_type:landmark|display=title}}

{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Goodyear Ballpark | nickname = | image = [[File:Goodyear Ballpark.PNG|125px]]
[[File:Goodyear Ballpark 1st Base Entrance.jpg|right|250px]] | location = 1933 S. Ballpark Way
[[Goodyear, Arizona|Goodyear]], [[Arizona|AZ]] 85338 | coordinates = {{coord|33|25|45|N|112|23|24|W|display=it}} | broke_ground = March 2008http://southwest.construction.com/features/archive/2009/0902_cover.asp | opened = February 21, 2009 | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Goodyear, AZ|City of Goodyear]] | operator = | surface = [[Grass]] | construction_cost = | architect = Populous | former_names = | tenants = [[Cleveland Indians]] ([[Spring Training]]) ([[MLB]]) (2009–present)
[[Cincinnati Reds]] ([[Spring Training]]) ([[MLB]]) (2010–present) | seating_capacity = 10,311 | dimensions = | website = http://www.goodyearbp.com/ }} '''Goodyear Ballpark''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Goodyear, Arizona]] (a western suburb of [[Phoenix, Arizona|Phoenix]]) and part of a $108 million[http://www.westvalleyview.com/main.asp?Search=1&ArticleID=33765&SectionID=12&SubSectionID=&S=1 A day for the fans] Accessed 8 June 2009 baseball complex that is the current [[spring training]] home of the [[Cleveland Indians]] and the [[Cincinnati Reds]]. The stadium opened to the public with a grand opening ceremony on February 21, 2009 and held its first [[Cactus League]] spring training baseball game on February 25, 2009.[http://www.westvalleyview.com/main.asp?Search=1&ArticleID=33845&SectionID=2&SubSectionID=&S=1 Opening day a hit] Accessed 8 June 2009 The stadium complex is owned by the city of Goodyear and contains the main field with a [[seating capacity]] of 10,311 along with several practice fields and team offices. The main entrance of the stadium is modern and uses surfaces mimicking dark stained wood and polished metal. The entrance houses a team shop, several concession stands and is decorated with Indians posters on the 1st base side and Reds on the 3rd base side. The entrance also has a third story terrace patio that can be rented for private parties. Outside the main entrance, the concourse features a 60-foot 6 inch fiberglass statue titled "The Ziz" created by artist [[Donald Lipski]]. The main entrance structure does not interfere with the inside the stadium which is a single tier of seating. Free standing polished metal awnings with fabric shades provide shelter from the sun down the third base line. Bullpens are located off the field in left and left center field. There is a large scoreboard in left field with general admission seating on a grass berm at its base. A cinder block concession stand in center field is painted dark green to provide a backdrop for the hitters. Right field features a second grass berm and a patio seating area and bar. The patio and bar area, like the Terrace patio, can be rented for private parties. There is a child play area with a [[Wiffle Ball]] field, inflatable batting and pitching games located on the first base side of the stadium. Goodyear Ballpark replaces [[Chain of Lakes Park]] in [[Winter Haven, Florida]], as the Indians' spring training home, and [[Ed Smith Stadium]] in [[Sarasota, Florida]], as the Reds' spring training home. The stadium is primarily used for [[baseball]] but also hosts community events such as the City of Goodyear's Star Spangled 4th, Fall Festival, and Home Plate for the Holidays. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.goodyearbp.com/ballpark-home-page Goodyear Ballpark Homepage] {{Cleveland Indians}} {{Cincinnati Reds}} {{Stadiums of the Cactus League}} {{Goodyear, Arizona}} [[Category:Cactus League venues]] [[Category:Cincinnati Reds spring training venues]] [[Category:Cleveland Indians spring training venues]] [[Category:Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Maricopa County, Arizona]] [[Category:2009 establishments in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Goodyear, Arizona]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Arizona League ballparks]]

{{Infobox hockey team | team = HK Gladiators Trnava | colour = Maroon | colour text = White | logo = | logosize = | city = [[Trnava]], [[Slovakia]] | league = [[Slovak 1.Liga]] | conference = | division = | founded = 1957 | arena = Zimny Stadion Trnava | colours = Red, White, Black | coach = Matej Sevcik | GM = | website = [http://www.hktrnava.sk/ hktrnava.sk] | name1 = | dates1 = | name2 = | dates2 = }} '''HK Trnava''' is an [[ice hockey]] team based in [[Trnava]], [[Slovakia]]. It plays in the [[Slovak 1.Liga]], the country's second division of ice hockey. The club was founded in 1957.
==History== [[Ice hockey]] is played in [[Trnava]] since 1923 when the first friendly game between ŠK Trnava and 1.ČsŠK Bratislava was played at the nature rink in Eagle Garden. Since 1935 Trnava played in western area with three clubs from Bratislava (Slavia, VŠ, ČsŠK) and Nitra, Nove Mesto nad Vahom, Topoľčany and other. However, the club was founded in 1957. Since the season 2004/05 [[Trnava]] is playing in the [[Slovak 1.Liga]].
==Club names== * Club of ice sports Spartak Trnava * Skating club * HK Trnava * HK Gladiators Trnava
==Sport achievements== * 1998/99 - 3. place in 1. hockey league * 1999/00 - 3. place in 1. hockey league * 2003/04 - first team was promoted to the 1. hockey league again, juniors under 20 and the team under 18 were promoted to the Extraliga * 2004/05 - 3. place u18 in Extraliga u18 * 2005/06 - 3. place u20 in Extraliga u20 * 2007/08 - 3. place in 1. hockey league * 2008/09 - 3. place in 1. hockey league * 2009/10 - 4. place in 1. hockey league * 2013/14 - 3. place in 1. hockey league * 2013/14 - 1. place u18 in 1. hockey league u18
==External links== * [http://www.hktrnava.sk/ Official site]

revision.text:
[[File:Jerome Park Racetrack 1868.jpg|right|thumb|Jerome Park Racetrack, 1868]] [[File:Jerome Park Racetrack 1886.jpg|right|thumb|Coaches at the racetrack, 1886]] '''Jerome Park Racetrack''' was an American [[Thoroughbred horse race|thoroughbred horse racing]] facility from 1866 until 1894. It was located in a part of [[Westchester County, New York]] that was annexed into [[the Bronx]] in 1874.
Jerome Park Racetrack was the home of the [[Belmont Stakes]] from 1867 until 1889.
==History== The racetrack opened in 1866 in the northwest part of [[Fordham, Bronx|Fordham]], [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]] (now in [[the Bronx]]), [[New York (state)|New York]]. Built on the old Bathgate estate, and operated by the [[American Jockey Club]], its owner/members were led by financier [[Leonard W. Jerome]] and [[August Belmont, Sr.]] A luxurious clubhouse was built near a rise that looked over the race course on what was known as "The Bluff".
In those days, many would come to the racing park by horse, coach and carriage, or by railroad at [[Fordham (NYCRR station)|Fordham Station]], located at the bottom of Fordham Hill and Rose Hill in [[Old Fordham Village]]. Later in the century, it would connect to [[Bedford Park (NYCRR station)|Bedford Park Station]].
The first [[Belmont Stakes]], the oldest of the three [[Triple Crown of Thoroughbred Racing#United States Triple Crowns|U.S. Triple Crown]] races which was named in honor of [[August Belmont, Sr.]], was held at Jerome Park Racetrack and continued to be run there until 1890 when it was moved to nearby [[Morris Park Racecourse]]. Jerome Park Racetrack was also the home to the [[Champagne Stakes (United States)|Champagne Stakes]] from its inaugural running in 1867 through 1889 and the [[Ladies Handicap]], created in 1868 and which today is run at [[Aqueduct Racetrack]] in [[Queens]] and is the oldest [[graded stakes race|stakes race]] in the United States exclusively for [[Filly|fillies]] and [[Mare (horse)|mares]].
In the spring of 1876, a group of [[polo]] enthusiasts founded the [[Westchester Polo Club]] at Jerome Park Racetrack. On May 13 of that year, the track was the site of the first outdoor [[Polo|polo match]] ever held in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |title=Playing Polo; The Games of the Polo Club, the Players and the Manner of Playing |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A01E5D8143FE63BBC4C52DFB366838D669FDE |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=May 14, 1876 |page=2 |accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportpolo.com/History/default.htm |title=History of the Equestrian Sport of Polo |publisher=sportpolo.com |accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref>
It is alleged that [[Lord Randolph Churchill]] first met Jerome's daughter, [[Jennie Jerome]], later to be courted and married, at the race park, but this allegation is false. As attested by Sir Winston Churchill in his biography of his father, Lord Randolph Churchill was never in America before his marriage, and the couple actually met in August 1873 at a ball on board the Imperial Russian cruiser "Ariadne" while it was moored at [[Cowes]] on the [[Isle of Wight]].<ref>https://archive.org/stream/lordrandolphchu01unkngoog#page/n70/mode/2up</ref> The track closed on October 4, 1894 to make way for the [[Jerome Park Reservoir]] that was needed for the metropolitan [[New York City water supply system]].<ref>{{cite news |title=The Racing for the Week; Close at Jerome and Opening at Morris Park |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9E01E1DA1131E033A25752C0A9669D94659ED7CF |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=October 1, 1894 |page=8 |accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=The End of Jerome Park; A Famous Race Course to be Turned into a City Reservoir |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A02E0DD143EEF33A25753C3A9649D94659ED7CF |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |date=December 30, 1894 |page=20 |accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref>
==Later land usage== [[File:Site plan for the Museum of the Peaceful Arts, New York City.jpg|right|thumb|Eastern half of Jerome Park with a proposed Museum of the Peaceful Arts, 1927]] The land that formed the western half of the Jerome Park Racetrack was turned into the [[Jerome Park Reservoir]]. The eastern half of the land was later used for:
* [[Kingsbridge Armory]] * [[Walton High School (Bronx)|Walton High School]] * [[Lehman College]] * [[The Bronx High School of Science]] * [[DeWitt Clinton High School]] * [[High School of American Studies]]
* [[List of New York City Subway yards#Jerome Yard|Jerome Yard]] * [[List of New York City Subway yards#Concourse Yard|Concourse Yard]] * [[High Pumping Station]] * Harris Field - a park of the New York City Department of Parks and Recreation. * Tracey Towers, and Scott Tower- residential buildings built over the Jerome Yard.
During the 1920s, the eastern half of the land was considered as a possible site for the [[Museum of the Peaceful Arts]].
==Other defunct New York race tracks== * [[Brighton Beach Race Course]] * [[Gravesend Race Track]] * [[Jamaica Racetrack]] * [[Morris Park Racecourse]] * [[Roosevelt Raceway (harness racing)|Roosevelt Raceway]] * [[Sheepshead Bay Race Track]] * [[Union Course]]
==References== {{Reflist}} * McNamara, John "''History in Asphalt: The Origin of Bronx Street and Place Names''" (1993) Bronx County Historical Society {{ISBN|978-0-941980-16-6}}

{{Infobox company | name = Le Coq Sportif | logo = Le coq sportif logo16.svg | logo_size = 180px | type = [[Public company|Public]] | industry = [[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] and [[Sports equipment|Sports Goods]] | products = [[Footwear]]
[[Fashion accessory|Accessories]]
[[Sportswear (activewear)|Sportswear]] | revenue = {{increase}} {{€|108 million|link=yes}} (2016){{cite web|url=http://airesis.ch/images/Airesis-RG_2016-web-opti.pdf|title=Rapport de gestion/Annual Report 2016|publisher=Airesis SA}} | net_income = | slogan = | homepage = {{URL|www.lecoqsportif.com}} | foundation = {{start date and age|1882}} | founder = [[Émile Camuset]] | location = [[Entzheim]], [[France]] }} '''Le Coq Sportif''' ({{IPA-fr|lə kɔk spɔʁtif}}, "the athletic rooster") is a French producer of [[athletic shoes]], [[activewear]], and sporting accessories. Founded in 1882 by [[Émile Camuset]] and located in [[Entzheim]], [[France]],{{cite web|url=http://www.superfiction.net/blog/index.php?2008/04/07/232-le-revival-du-coq-sportif|title=superfiction.net/blog|author=|date=|website=superfiction.net|accessdate=16 April 2018}} the company first issued items branded with its now-famous rooster trademark in 1948.[http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion_central/companies/fashion/le_coq_sportif Vogue Australia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070904111555/http://www.vogue.com.au/fashion_central/companies/fashion/le_coq_sportif |date=2007-09-04 }} The company's name and trademark are derived from the [[Gallic rooster]], a [[national symbol]] of France. ==Sponsorships== [[File:Logo le coq sportif.png|thumb|Le Coq Sportif old logo]] [[File:Le Coq Sportif, Mercer Street, London 01.jpg|thumb|Le Coq Sportif shop, [[Mercer Street, London]]]] The company has [[sponsor (commercial)|sponsorship]] deals with several [[Association football|football]] clubs, most notably European clubs [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] and [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]]. In addition, the company sponsors the [[Quick Step-Innergetic]] and [[Team Milram]] cycling teams. Le coq sportif also supplied kits to the [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] team that won the [[FA Cup]] in 1981 and 1982, [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] 1982 team that won the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]], [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]], [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]],{{cite news|title=Sunderland|accessdate=24 July 2016|first=Dave|last=Moor|publisher=Historical Football Kits|work=historicalkits.co.uk|url=http://historicalkits.co.uk/Sunderland/Sunderland.htm}} [[Sheffield United F.C.|Sheffield United]]{{cite news|title=Sheffield United|accessdate=24 July 2016|first=Dave|last=Moor|publisher=Historical Football Kits|work=historicalkits.co.uk|url=http://historicalkits.co.uk/Sheffield_United/Sheffield_United.htm}} and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]]{{cite news|title=Everton|accessdate=24 July 2016|first=Dave|last=Moor|publisher=Historical Football Kits|work=historicalkits.co.uk|url=http://historicalkits.co.uk/Everton/Everton.htm}} and [[AFC Ajax]] of [[Amsterdam]]{{cite news|url=http://www.ajaxcafe.nl/De-Club/|accessdate=24 July 2016|work=ajaxcafe.nl|language=Dutch|title=AFC Ajax en alles eromheen|trans-title=AFC Ajax and everything around it|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150127174721/http://www.ajaxcafe.nl/De-Club/|archivedate=27 January 2015|deadurl=no}} of the mid-1980s; the [[FIFA World Cup]] winning teams of [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in 1982 and [[Argentina national football team|Argentina]] in 1986. The company also sponsored Brazilian club [[Sport Club Internacional]] in 1982. The club won the traditional [[Joan Gamper Trophy]] at the [[Camp Nou]] in Barcelona while using Le Coq uniforms. Internacional also won the 1982 [[Gaúcho Championship]] wearing Le Coq. South Korean [[golf]]er [[Yang Yong-eun]] wore a Le Coq Sportif shirt on the last day of the [[PGA Championship]] in 2009, which he won.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} Le Coq Sportif is famous{{to whom|date=July 2016}} in Japan and Korea and hired local designers to complete and adapt the global collection for local market. They also signed some partnerships to release special models. Le Coq Sportif in Japan associated with Sou to create handmade shoes and ''[[tabi]]''.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} They also released a line of shoes with designer Kamishima Chinami.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} For Le Coq Sportif Korea, the partnership was made with the car manufacturer [[Peugeot]] to create a shoe named the "Peugeot 207cc." The shoes were recalled in 2009 for a product fault, when the fabric was exposed to water the shoe's stitching would come apart.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} This in turn lost Le Coq Sportif millions in revenue.{{citation needed|date=July 2016}} In 2012, Le Coq Sportif returned to professional [[cycling]], and manufactured the jerseys for the [[Tour de France]] under a new five-year contract with [[Amaury Sport Organisation]]. Le Coq Sportif started supplying the Tour de France in 1951. Le Coq Sportif is the official uniform supplier of the following teams/players: ===Basketball=== *{{flagicon|KOR}} [[Changwon LG Sakers]] ===Boxing=== *{{flagicon|England}} [[Lennox Lewis]] ===Cycling=== *{{flagicon|France}} [[Tour de France]] ===Tennis=== *{{flagicon|France}} [[Richard Gasquet]]{{cite web|url=https://www.lequipe.fr/Tennis/Actualites/Gasquet-avec-le-coq-sportif/428686|title=Gasquet avec le Coq Sportif|first=|last=Rédaction|date=|website=lequipe.fr|accessdate=16 April 2018}} *{{flagicon|KOR}} [[Chung Hyeon]] ===Football=== *{{flagicon|ARG}} [[Club de Gimnasia y Esgrima La Plata|Gimnasia y Esgrima La Plata]] *{{flagicon|BRA}} [[Quimbaya Brasil F.C|Quimbaya Brasil]] *{{flagicon|FRA}} [[AS Saint-Étienne|Saint-Étienne]] *{{flagicon|ITA}} [[ACF Fiorentina|Fiorentina]] *{{flagicon|ITA}} [[AS Velasca]] *{{flagicon|KOR}} [[FC Seoul]] *{{flagicon|Lebanon}} [[Homenmen Beirut]] ====Former national teams==== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Lietuvos rytas Arena | image = [[File:Lietuvos Rytas arena.jpg|260 px|Lietuvos rytas home courts: Lietuvos rytas Arena and Siemens Arena.]] | nickname = | address = Ozo g. 14A | location = [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]] | broke_ground = | opened = September 28, 2005 | expanded = 2014 | owner = [[BC Lietuvos rytas]] | construction_cost = 2.3 million [[EUR]] | contractor = | architect = | capacity = 2,500 | record_attendance = 2,390 ([[BC Lietuvos rytas|Lietuvos rytas]] v [[BC Oostende|Oostende]], 11 February 2015)[http://www.eurocupbasketball.com/eurocup/games/results/showgame?gamecode=271&seasoncode=U2014 Lietuvos Rytas-Telenet Ostend boxscore] | tenants =[[BC Lietuvos rytas|Lietuvos rytas Vilnius]]
[[BC Kibirkštis Vilnius|Kibirkštis Vilnius]]
[[Perlas (basketball club)|Vilniaus Perlas]] }} '''Lietuvos rytas Arena''' is a 2,500-seat [[basketball]] arena in [[Vilnius]], [[Lithuania]], built next to [[Siemens Arena]].{{cite web|title=Lithuanian Basketball League |publisher=Lithuanian Basketball League |url=http://www.lkl.lt/index.php/b19sYW5nPWhlJm9fc2Vhcz04Jm9fbGVhZz0xJmZ1c2VhY3Rpb249dGVhbXMub3RoZXImdD01Mw== |accessdate=2009-10-17 |language=lt |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081016012212/http://www.lkl.lt/index.php/b19sYW5nPWhlJm9fc2Vhcz04Jm9fbGVhZz0xJmZ1c2VhY3Rpb249dGVhbXMub3RoZXImdD01Mw%3D%3D |archivedate=2008-10-16 |df= }} [[BC Lietuvos rytas|Lietuvos rytas Vilnius]] play the [[Lietuvos krepšinio lyga|Lithuanian Basketball League]]'s home matches in the arena. More important or highly anticipated matches in the LKL, as well as all home fixtures in European competitions (such as the [[EuroLeague]] or [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]]), are played in the [[Siemens Arena]]. Women basketball team [[BC Kibirkštis Vilnius|Kibirkštis Vilnius]] also plays in Lietuvos Rytas arena. Past tenants include now dissolved Lithuanian and European women's basketball powerhouse [[Vilniaus Teo|Teo]] and Lietuvos Rytas daughter club [[BC Perlas|Perlas Vilnius]]. In 2014, its capacity was expanded from 1,700 seats to 2,500 seats with the aim to host [[EuroCup Basketball|EuroCup]] games.[http://www.lrytas.lt/sportas/krepsinis/pasizvalgykite-po-atnaujinta-lietuvos-ryto-arena.htm Pasižvalgykite po atnaujintą „Lietuvos ryto“ areną] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141016022625/http://www.lrytas.lt/sportas/krepsinis/pasizvalgykite-po-atnaujinta-lietuvos-ryto-arena.htm |date=2014-10-16 }} ==References== {{reflist}} {{coord|54.717|N|25.282|E|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Lithuania]] [[Category:Sports venues in Vilnius]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2005]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Lithuania]] [[Category:Šeškinė]] {{Lithuania-sports-venue-stub}}

{{About|the Algerian football club|other uses|Mouloudia (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = MSP Batna | image = [[Image:MSP Batna.png|150px|Logo]] | fullname = Mouloudia Sportive Populaire de Batna | nickname = Boubiya
Bianconeri | founded = [[1962 in association football|1962]]
(as ''Mouloudia Sportif Populaire de Batna'') | ground = [[Stade 1er Novembre (Batna)|Stade 1er Novembre]] | capacity = 25,000 | chrtitle = President | chairman = | mgrtitle = Head Coach | manager = | league = [[Inter-Régions Division]] | season = [[2017–18 Inter-Régions Division|2017–18]] | position = | current = 2018–19 MSP Batna season | pattern_la1 =_blackshoulders | pattern_b1 = _whitestripes | pattern_ra1 =_blackshoulders | leftarm1 = FFFFFF | body1 = 000000 | rightarm1 = FFFFFF | shorts1 = 000000 | socks1 = 000000 | pattern_la2= | pattern_b2= | pattern_ra2= | leftarm2=FFFFFF | body2=FFFFFF | rightarm2=FFFFFF | shorts2=008000 | socks2=FFFFFF }} '''Mouloudia Sportive Populaire de Batna''' ({{lang-ar|المولودية الرياضية الشعبية باتنة}}), known as '''MSP Batna''' or simply '''MSPB''' for short, is an Algerian football club based in the city of [[Batna City|Batna]], [[Algeria]]. The club was founded on 1962 and its colours are black, green and white. Their home stadium, [[Stade 1er Novembre (Batna)|Stade 1er Novembre]], has a capacity of 25,000 spectators. The club is currently playing in the [[Inter-Régions Division]]. ==Current squad== ''As of September 2018'' {{Cite web|url=http://www.dzfoot.com/effectifs/effectifs.php?club_id=60&saison_id=16|title=Effectifs des clubs - DZFOOT.COM|website=www.dzfoot.com|access-date=2017-09-15}} ==Honours== * '''[[Algerian Championnat National]]: 1''' ::Runner-up (1): 1965 * '''[[Algerian Cup]]:''' ::Finalist: 1989 [[MC Lakouablia]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.dzfoot.com/clubs/clubs.php?club_id=60 DZFoot.com Team Page] {{Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 2}} {{Algerian Championnat National}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Batna, MSP}} [[Category:Football clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1962]] [[Category:Batna Province|Msp Batna]] [[Category:Algerian Ligue Professionnelle 2 clubs]] [[Category:1962 establishments in Algeria]] [[Category:Sports clubs in Algeria]] [[Category:Batna, Algeria]] {{Algeria-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | fullname = Managua Futbol Club | image = Managua FC Logo.png | image_size = 200px | clubname = Managua F.C. | nickname = ''La Maquinaria Azul'',
''Los Leones Azules'' | founded = 2006 | ground = [[Estadio Olímpico del IND Managua]] | capacity = 9,000 | chairman = | manager = Emilio Aburto | league = [[Primera División de Nicaragua|Primera División]], [[Nicaragua]] | season = [[2015–16 Primera División de Nicaragua|2015 Apertura]] | position = 7th | pattern_la1 = _yellowborder | pattern_b1 = _yellowhorizontal | pattern_ra1 = _yellowborder | pattern_sh1 = _adidasyellow | pattern_so1 = _3 stripes yellow | leftarm1 = 0022cc | body1 = 0022cc | rightarm1 = 0022cc | shorts1 = 0022cc | socks1 = 0000cc | pattern_la2 = _yellowborder | pattern_b2 = _yellowhorizontal | pattern_ra2 = _yellowborder | pattern_sh2 = _adidasyellow | pattern_so2 = _3 stripes yellow | leftarm2 = ff0033 | body2 = ff0033 | rightarm2 = ff0033 | shorts2 = ff0033 | socks2 = ff0033 }} '''Managua Futbol Club''' is a professional [[association football|football]] [[football club|club]] based in [[Managua]], [[Nicaragua]] which currently plays in the [[Nicaraguan Primera División|Nicaraguan Premier Division]]. ==History== The team was promoted to the [[Nicaraguan Primera División|Primera División]] for the first time in their history in 2009–10 after beating [[América Managua|Deportivo América]] in a two-legged [[Segunda División de Nicaragua|Segunda División]] championship final.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesn/nica2010.html#2final Nicaragua 2009/10] - RSSSF They made an immediate impact on the top flight, qualifying for the semifinals in their first season (Apertura 2010). Since then, they have been a regular playoff participant and even reached the finals of the 2017 Apertura, losing on away goals to Walter Ferretti. ==Achievements== *'''[[Primera División de Nicaragua]]: 1''' ::Runners-up (1): Apertura 2017 *'''[[Segunda División de Nicaragua]]: 1''' ::2009–10 ==First Division record (2010–Present)== ''Apertura 2010 – Present'' {|class="wikitable" ! align="center"|Season ! align="center"|Position ! align="center"|GP ! align="center"|W ! align="center"|D ! align="center"|L ! align="center"|GF ! align="center"|GA ! align="center"|PTS ! align="center"|Play-offs ! align="center"|Pl. ! align="center"|W ! align="center"|D ! align="center"|L ! align="center"|GS ! align="center"|GA ! align="center"|PTS |- |- |align="center"|[[2010–11 Primera División de Nicaragua|2010 Apertura]]||align="center"|3rd||

{{IIHFnation |IIHFnation = Mongolia |bg_color = red |text_color = white |logo_image = Mongolian_Hockey_Federation_logo.svg |organization = Mongolian Hockey Federation |code = MGL |joined = May 15, 1999 |president = Sumiya Ganjargal |mens_ranking = 50<ref name=ranking>[http://www.iihf.com/home-of-hockey/championships/world-ranking/mens-world-ranking/2016-ranking/ 2016 IIHF Men's World Ranking]</ref> |womens_ranking = N/A }} The '''Mongolian Hockey Federation''' ({{lang-mn|Монголын Хоккейн Холбоо}}) is the governing body of ice hockey in [[Mongolia]]. It controls the six team national league in Mongolia, as well as the [[Mongolian national ice hockey team]], whose first appearance in an [[IIHF]] event was the [[2007 IIHF World Championship Division III]] tournament. They have since taken part in the [[2008 IIHF World Championship Division III]]. On October 2012, their last appearance was the [[2013 IIHF World Championship Division III]] Qualification in [[Abu Dhabi]], [[United Arab Emirates]].
== References ==
{{reflist}} * [http://www.nhl.com/nhl/app/?service=page&page=NewsPage&articleid=335204 NHL.com article on Mongolian ice hockey] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130726025817/http://beijinghockey.com/mongolia/index.htm Mongolian Hockey Federation, Courtesy of Beijing International]
== External links == * [http://www.iihf.com/iihf-home/countries/mongolia/ Mongolia] at [http://www.iihf.com/ IIHF.com] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120719160934/http://www.beijinghockey.com/mongolia/nhlnews07.htm Beijing International work with Mongolian Hockey Federation]

{{refimprove|date=January 2017}} {{Infobox cricket team | name = Sandyford Cricket Club | image = [[File:sandyfordcc logo.png]] | oneday_name = | second_team = | coach = | bowlingcoach = | fielding_coach = | captain = | od_captain = | overseas = | colors = | founded = 1984 | ground = [[Marlay Park]] | capacity = | owner = | ceo = | manager = | adviser = | first_fc = | first_fc_year = | first_fc_venue = | title1 = | title1wins = | title2 = | title2wins = | title3 = | title3wins = | title4 = | title4wins = | website = [http://www.sandyfordcc.org www.sandyfordcc.org] }} '''Sandyford Cricket Club''' was founded in 1984 <ref>Cliff Kennedy, founding member (2005), ''http://www.sandyfordcc.org/history''</ref> in the [[Dublin]] suburb of [[Sandyford]]. The club's home ground is located in [[Marlay Park]], a 300-acre public park, about nine kilometers from [[Dublin]] city center. The club is a member of the Leinster Cricket Union <ref>http://www.cricketleinster.ie/clubs/sandyford</ref> and currently fields two senior teams across various divisions.
'''Club Honours''':
1st team league titles (6): 1985 (Junior B), 1990 (Junior A), 1995 (Intermediate B), 1996 (Intermediate A), 2002 (Middle A), 2016 (Division 7).
2nd team league titles (4): 1989 (Junior B), 1994 (Junior B), 2006 (Junior A), 2008 (Intermediate B).
3rd team league titles (1): 2008 (Junior B).
'''Cup Final Victories'''
2008 Middle 2 Cup Final Sandyford I beat Knockharley
2008 Whelan Cup Final Sandyford II beat Rush
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.sandyfordcc.org Sandyford Cricket Club website]

revision.text:
A '''speed skating rink''' (or '''speed skating oval''') is an [[ice rink]] (but also a ''[[sport venue]]'') in which a [[speed skating]] competition is held.
==The rink== A standard [[long track speed skating]] track is, according to the regulations of the [[International Skating Union]] (ISU), a double-laned track with two curved ends each of 180°, in which the radius of the inner curve is not less than 25 metres and not more than 26 metres. The width of the competition lanes is 4 metres. At the opposite straight of the finishing line, there is a crossing area, where the skaters must change lane. [ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules] - Rule 203
At international competitions, the track must be 400 metres long, with a warm-up lane at least 4 metres wide inside the competition lanes.<ref>ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules - Rule 205</ref> For Olympic competitions, the track must also be enclosed within a building.<ref>ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules - Rule 206</ref>
The design and dimensions of a speed skating track have remained more or less unchanged since the foundation of ISU in 1892.
The speed skating track is also used for the sports of [[Icetrack cycling]] and [[Ice speedway]]
=== Measurement and demarcation === [[File:Speedskating rink 400 meters with dimensions.svg|thumb|300px|The dimensions of a standard speed skating rink]]
The measurement of the track is made half a meter into the lane.<ref>ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules - Rule 228</ref> The total length of the track is the distance a competitor skates each lap, i.e. the length of two straights, one inner curve and one outer curve, in addition to the extra distance skated when changing lanes in the cross-over area, which on a standard track equals 7 centimeters.
*A 400 m track with inner radius 25.0 m has 113.57 m long straights *A 400 m track with inner radius 25.5 m has 112.00 m long straights *A 400 m track with inner radius 26.0 m has 110.43 m long straights
The demarcation of the competition lanes are made by painted lines in the ice (ot a set of painted marks) and movable blocks of rubber. On outdoor tracks, snow may also be used for demarcation of the competition lanes.<ref>ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules - Rule 226</ref>
===Alternative speed skating tracks=== Although ISU regulations state that minimum measures for a standard speed skating track, alternative track lengths may be used for competition. The minimum requirements are track length on 200 meters, radius of inner curve of 15  meters and width of the competition lanes 2 meters.<ref>ISU Special Regulations and Technical Rules - Rule 204</ref>
[[Short track speed skating]] tracks have a length of 111.111 metres (364.54 ft). The rink is 60 metres (200 ft) long by 30 metres (98 ft) wide, which is the same size as an international-sized [[ice hockey rink]].
==Combination with other sports== [[Image:Bandy in Medeu Kazakhstan.JPG|thumb|right|300px|[[Medeu]] is also suitable for [[bandy]]]] Many speed skating venues have ice hockey rinks or no ice area at all inside the oval. A few are suitable also for [[bandy]], like [[Hamar Olympic Hall]],<ref>[http://arkiv.bandyforbundet.no/bandy/bilder/bandytrening.jpg bandyforbundet.no]</ref> [[Ice Palace Krylatskoye]],<ref>[http://cdn1.img.rsport.ru/images/90185/92/901859281.jpg image at rsport.ru]</ref> and [[Medeu]].<ref>[http://www.on.kz/userdata/10152/blogpost_photos/3246678c82a4e2a4fa3ce90a304d4ac8.JPG image at on.kz]</ref> The [[National Speed Skating Oval]] in Beijing, China, which is in the process of being built for the [[2022 Winter Olympics]], is also designed appropriately for that sport.<ref>[http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2017-04/27/content_29104802.htm Beijing unveils design of speed skating venue for Olympics]</ref><ref>[https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http://www.kuzbassbandyclub.ru/mainnews/archive/3698]</ref> There is a growing cooperation between [[International Skating Union]] and [[Federation of International Bandy]], since both have an interest in more indoor venues with large ice surfaces being built.<ref>[https://translate.google.co.uk/translate?hl=en&sl=ru&u=http://www.kuzbassbandyclub.ru/mainnews/archive/3698 kuzbassbandyclub.ru]</ref> In Norway there is an agreement in place, stating that an indoor arena intended primarily for either bandy or long track speed skating, shall have ice surface for the other sport as well.
== Indoor speed skating tracks == {{Main|List of indoor speed skating rinks}} Below is a complete list of the indoor 400 m speed skating tracks around the world. The data presented are retrieved from the online database Speed Skating News.<ref name=ssn>[http://www.speedskatingnews.info Speed Skating News]</ref>

revision.text:
{{hatnote|"Tagalong" redirects here. It is not to be confused with [[Tagalog (disambiguation)|Tagalog]]. For the cookie, see [[Girl Scout Cookies]].}} [[File:Jednokołowy rowerek dziecięcy.jpg|thumb|Side view of a single-speed, seatpost mounted trailer bike]] [[File:Half Wheeler - bike.JPG|thumb|Single speed Half wheeler attached at the seat post]]
A '''trailer bike''' (also known as a '''trailer cycle''', and trademarked names such as '''Trailerbike''', '''Trail-a-bike''', '''Half wheeler''' or '''Tagalong''') is a one-wheeled, or sometimes two-wheeled, [[bicycle trailer]] designed to carry one or more children in positions that closely resemble that of a bicycle rider. It can be described as the, "back half of a bicycle."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ctc.org.uk/DesktopDefault.aspx?TabID=3614 | title = CTC - the UK's national cyclists' organisation: Trailer-cycle | accessdate = 2007-04-01 }}</ref> The rider of a trailer bike usually has a [[Bicycle saddle|saddle]], [[Bicycle handlebar|handlebars]], and [[Bicycle pedal|pedals]]. Some fold for more compact storage.
==History== The trailer bike was patented by Canadian entrepreneur Delbert Adams.<ref>{{cite book | title = United States Patent No. 379,782| url = https://books.google.com/patents/about?id=kuIlAAAAEBAJ | accessdate = 2009-10-01}}</ref> Adams started the manufacturer of trailer bikes, Trail-a-Bike, and began selling them in the early 1990s,<ref>{{Citation |title= Kids in the 'awkward years' of cycling? Try a trailer bike.| newspaper= [[Star Tribune]] |location=[[Minneapolis, Minnesota]] |date= June 5, 1996 | first=Bill |last= Hammond|url = http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-62630743.html }} {{subscription required|via=HighBeam}}</ref> although the same concept had been previously independently and imitatively invented by others at least as far back as the 1930s with the Rann Trailer.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.ctc.org.uk/DesktopDefault.aspx?TabID=3614 | title = CTC - the UK's national cyclists' organisation: Trailer-cycle | accessdate = 2007-04-01 }}</ref>
==Configurations== Trailer bikes have come in a variety of configurations. These include upright-bicycle-like seating, and recumbent-bicycle-like seating as with the Weehoo iGo.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://reviews.mtbr.com/review-weehoo-igo-pro-child-bike-seat | title = Review: Weehoo iGo Pro child bike seat | author = Linda Bookman | date = December 19, 2014 | publisher = MTBR.com | accessdate = 2015-06-26}}</ref> Trailer bikes have been available in single-seat and [[Tandem bicycle|tandem]] configurations.<ref>{{cite web| url = http://www.gopbc.org/bike_support/adams_tandem.jpg | title = GOPBC.org Active Passenger Trailers | accessdate = 2007-04-01 }}</ref> Trailer bikes may have just one [[Bicycle gearing|gear]] or more than one. They seldom have [[Bicycle brake systems|brakes]].
==Attachments== A trailer bike is attached to a bicycle at either the [[seatpost]] or on a special rear [[Luggage carrier|rack]] by a linkage that allows for pivoting. Alternatively, the hitch mechanism may rotate using the seatpost as the pivot. The attachment may include a quick-release option.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.sheldonbrown.com/harris/adams-trail-a-bike.html | title = The Adams Trail-A-Bike! at SheldonBrown.com| accessdate = 2007-04-01 }}</ref>
==Variations== The Trail-Gator tow bar and FollowMe Tandem coupling are two products that convert an existing, complete kid's bike into a trailer bike.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.twowheelingtots.com/trail-gator/ | title = Trail Gator Trailer Cycle-Review | author = Lisa | publisher = Two Wheeling Tots | accessdate = 2015-06-26}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.simplypropelled.com/single-post/2017/02/20/FollowMe-Tandem-Review | title = FollowMe Tandem Review | author = Dan Clark | publisher = Simply Propelled | accessdate = 2018-04-29}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery> Image:Family Ride bicycle cycle trailer.jpg|Adult and two children cycling using two-wheeled tandem trailer bike (a Pashley U+2) Image:Bikefor45bbtjeh.JPG|Tandem + two trailer bikes + cargo trailer for family of four Image:TeddyChauffeursTiny.jpg|A Burley Piccolo behind a triple tandem File:IGo by Weehoo Inc.jpg|A recumbent IGo by Weehoo File:Trailercycle.jpg|Rear rack attachment as alternative to seatpost attachment File:Recumbent trailer bike.jpg|A recumbent two-wheeled Trets trailer bike by [[Hase Spezialräder|Hase]] on the back of a tandem File:Vlečení kola.jpg|A complete child's bike converted into a trailer bike File:Bici i followme.JPG|A complete child's bike converted into a trailer bike </gallery>
==See also== {{Commons category|Trailer bikes}} * [[Outline of cycling]] *[[Quadracycle (human-powered vehicle)]] *[[Tricycle]]

[[Ryder Cup]]   [[2008 Ryder Cup|(2008)]]
[[Senior PGA Championship]] (2004, 2011) |website = [http://valhalla.pgalinks.com/ valhalla.pgalinks.com] |course1 = |designer1 = [[Jack Nicklaus]] |par1 = 71 |length1 = {{convert|7458|yd}}{{cite web |url=http://valhalla.pgalinks.com/index.cfm?page=course_information&subpage=course_tour |publisher=Valhalla Golf Club |title=Course tour |accessdate=July 19, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131008001358/http://valhalla.pgalinks.com/index.cfm?page=course_information&subpage=course_tour |archivedate=October 8, 2013 |df= }} |rating1 = 76.4 |slope1 = 148 {{cite web |url=http://ncrdb.usga.org/NCRDB/courseTeeInfo.aspx?CourseID=28073 |publisher=USGA |title=Course Rating and Slope Database: Valhalla Golf Club |accessdate=July 19, 2013}} |record1 = }} {{Location map |USA |relief = 1 |label = Valhalla
Golf Club |lat = 38.242 |long = -85.472 |caption = Location in the [[United States]] |float = |background= |width = 240 }} [[File:Zenos Frudakis Jack Nicklaus Louisville.jpg|thumb|Statue of Jack Nicklaus and Dwight Gahm by [[Zenos Frudakis]] at Valhalla in 2008]] '''Valhalla Golf Club''', located east of [[Louisville, Kentucky]], is a private golf club designed by [[Jack Nicklaus]], opened in 1986. In 1992, Valhalla was selected to host the [[PGA Championship]] in the year [[1996 PGA Championship|1996]], one of golf's four [[Men's major golf championships|majors]]. The following year (1993), the [[Professional Golfers' Association of America|PGA of America]] purchased a 25% interest in the club. After the championship in 1996, the PGA of America raised its stake to 50% and announced that the event would return to Valhalla in [[2000 PGA Championship|2000]]. At its conclusion, the PGA of America exercised an option to purchase the remaining interest in the club. Later that year, it announced that the [[Ryder Cup]] would be held at Valhalla in [[2008 Ryder Cup|2008]]. Valhalla also hosted the [[PGA Club Professional Championship]] in 2002 and the [[Senior PGA Championship]] in 2004. The PGA Championship was originally scheduled to be played at Valhalla in [[2004 PGA Championship|2004]], but the PGA of America switched it to [[Whistling Straits]] in [[Wisconsin]].{{cite web|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LH&s_site=kentucky&p_multi=LH&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB734D6021DC3B1&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Lexington Herald Leader: Search Results|publisher=}} In 2009, the PGA of America announced that the Senior PGA Championship and the PGA Championship would return to Valhalla in 2011 and 2014, respectively. The course sits on a {{convert|486|acre|km2|sing=on|1}} property on Shelbyville Road ([[U.S. Route 60 in Kentucky|US 60]]) in the eastern portion of Louisville just outside the Gene Snyder Freeway ([[Interstate 265|I-265]]) It was envisioned by local business leader Dwight Gahm (pronounced "game") and his three sons in 1981, and opened five years later. Steve Houg is the head professional as of March 2016. ==Major tournaments hosted== The 1996 PGA Championship was won in a playoff; [[Mark Brooks (golfer)|Mark Brooks]] won his only major title with a birdie on the first extra hole, the par-5 18th. [[Franklin, Kentucky|Franklin]] native [[Kenny Perry]] was the runner-up in the event's final sudden-death playoff. Four years later, the 2000 PGA Championship also went to a playoff; [[Tiger Woods]] won by one stroke over [[Bob May (golfer)|Bob May]] in the revised three-hole format. Woods had a 3-4-5=12 to May's 4-4-5=13 on the course's final three holes. It was Woods' second consecutive PGA Championship, his fifth major title and his third consecutive major title (beginning with the [[2000 U.S. Open (golf)|2000 US Open]] - a streak that continued into the "Tiger Slam" at the [[2001 Masters Tournament|2001 Masters]].) Valhalla hosted its third PGA Championship in 2014, when [[Rory McIlroy]] beat [[Phil Mickelson]] also by one stroke.{{cite web|title=PGA Championship|url=http://www.pga.com/pgachampionship/event/information/2014-pga-championship-area-information|website=pga.com|publisher=PGA/Turner Sports Interactive|accessdate=7 November 2014}} Beforehand, the course had undergone a major "modernization" after it hosted the Senior PGA Championship in 2011, which included the rebuilding of all 18 greens.{{cite news|url=http://www.courier-journal.com/article/20130803/SPORTS10/308030091/Green-light-Valhalla-Renovation-putting-surfaces-draws-praise-one-year-out-from-PGA-Championship |newspaper=Louisville Courier-Journal|last=Sokeland |first=Justin |title=Green light at Valhalla: Renovation of putting surfaces draws praise one year out from PGA Championship |date=August 4, 2013 |accessdate=August 4, 2013}} In addition, Valhalla hosted the [[Ryder Cup]] in [[2008 Ryder Cup|2008]], with the United States defeating Europe 16½ to 11½ for the first U.S. win since their comeback victory in [[1999 Ryder Cup|1999]] at [[The Country Club]] in [[Brookline, Massachusetts]]. Perry and another native Kentuckian – [[J. B. Holmes]] of [[Campbellsville, Kentucky|Campbellsville]], who made the team as one of American captain [[Paul Azinger]]'s four picks - were part of the victorious Team USA and accounted for a combined five points. {| class="wikitable" !Year!!Tournament!!Winner !Winning Score !Margin of Victory !Runner(s) Up !Winner's Share ($) |- | align=center|'''[[1996 PGA Championship|1996]]''' || [[PGA {{Infobox hockey team | team = WAT Stadlau | colour = Red | colour text = White | logo = | logosize = | city = [[Vienna]], [[Austria]] | league = [[Austrian Hockey League]] | conference = | division = | founded = 1914 | arena = | colours = | coach = | GM = | website = | name1 = | dates1 = | name2 = | dates2 = }} '''WAT Stadlau''' (short for Wiener [[Arbeitsgemeinschaft für Sport und Körperkultur in Österreich|ASKÖ]] Team Stadlau ) is a sport club in [[Vienna]] [[Donaustadt]], [[Austria]]. The club celebrated his biggest success in ice hockey and Judo. The ice hockey team played in the [[Austrian Hockey League]], the top level of ice hockey in Austria, and the [[Austrian National League]], the second level Austrian league. The ice hockey division folded in 1991.
==Achievements: Ice Hockey== *1971-72: 3rd place in Austrian Hockey League *1979-80: 1st place in Austrian National League *1983-84: 3rd place in Austrian Hockey League
==Achievements: Judo== * 1983: 8th place Austrian National League (men) * 1988: 8th place Austrian National League (men) * 2013: 2nd place Austrian League (women) * 2015: 3rd place Austrian League (women)
==External links== *[http://www.wat-stadlau.at/ Homepage of WAT Stadlau] *[http://www.hockeyarenas.net/index.php?page=4000&c=wl&lcID=at&cupID=eu&type=0&tmID=1250 Club profile] on Hockeyarenas.net
